_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The safety of our employees, contract employees, customers, neighbors and the environment is a core business value and an important priority. Reducing the impact of our operations on the environment is also a priority. NuStar Energy LP is committed to achieving Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) excellence throughout the organization.

NuStar management has also agreed to correct in a timely manner all hazards identified through self inspections, employee reports, accident investigations, or any other means with interim protection as necessary.

We will provide the results of self-inspections and accident investigation to our employees upon request.

We will continuously seek areas for improvement and ways to raise our employees level of awareness regarding all aspects of safety and health.

The Norfolk Terminal was built and put into service in 1959. The facility was built to store and transport propane (RMP regulated substance), refined products and a Liquid Mixture (LM) of the two products. The propane, refined products and the LM are delivered, via a 6 inch and an 8 inch pipeline, to the Norfolk Terminal from the NuStar Terminal in Geneva, Nebraska. The 810,000 lbs. of propane, which exceeds the 10,000 lbs. threshold quantity (TQ) of the OSHA PSM requirements, is stored in, one of two, pressurized bullet tanks. The LM is stored in two pressurized bullet tanks and is routed through a Depropanizer distillation process, which removes any excess propane from the LM and this propane is then stored in the propane bullet tanks with the good propane. The propane is then removed from the site by propane trucks that deliver it to various customers.

The Norfolk Facility complies with many different regulatory agencies, which include, but not limited to;

- OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) Program (1910.119) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

- OSHAs Emergency Action Plan Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.38(c).

- OSHAs HAZWOPER Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.120.

- Federal Oil Pollution Act of 1990: U.S. DOT Final Rule for Transportation Related On-Shore Facilities as published in 

  49 CFR Part 194 (Response Plans for Onshore Oil Pipelines).

- Federal Oil Pollution Act of 1990: U.S. EPA Final Rule for non-Transportation Related on-Shore Facilities as published 

  in 40 CFR Part 112.

- DOT Part 195 Transportation of Hazardous Liquids by Pipeline.

- DOT Part 199 Drug and Alcohol Testing.

The Norfolk Facility conducts two equipment deployment drills (one un-announced) a year, Quarterly Qualified Individual (QI) drills and an annual table top drill is performed during the annual HAZWOPER training. 

We have an excellent five year accident free history. We have had no accidental releases in the last five years and in fact the Norfolk Terminal was built in 1959 and to this date we have had zero propane releases. 

The Norfolk Emergency Response Program works together with the Norfolk Fire Department. The Norfolk employees are not first responders, but have received training in the notification process of the Norfolk Fire Department (first responder). The employees also participate in an annual evacuation drill, in the event an evacuation is required. 

Various employees at the Norfolk Terminal have received CPR training, and all employees have received annual HAZWOPER training. Numerous other drills are conducted at the Norfolk Terminal as stated previously.

Safety is the #1 core value of our company. Whether in performing everyday work or in the planning and maintenance of project work, safety is top priority. Some of the future improvements towards safety are: 

- Management and employees are teaming together to pursue the OSHA VPP Star award. In this pursuit, there are several 

  changes planned to improve safety and some of them are;

- Quarterly Hazard Identification Audits

- Electrical cord quarterly inspection program

- First Use Vehicle inspection program

- Lifting sling(s) quarterly inspection program

- The

regional office has implemented an electronic MOC process, which has helped expedite the approval process and 

  provide a more in-depth safety analysis of the proposed change.

- An electronic SDS (MSDS) approval process has been completed which allows all users at any of the sites the ability to

  view any SDS through the company intranet.

- The entire region uses the company CEM (Certified Environmental Management) to perform the Industrial Hygiene testing.

- NuStar has implemented automatic tank gauging which alleviates the need to climb the tanks on a daily basis.
